Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Women's Empowerment, Food Security and Farm Productivity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the implications of development initiatives that seek to empower women and enhance gender equity in developing countries, using the dairy sector in Uganda as a field site. In Uganda, as in many developing countries, women dominate the agricultural labor force, yet gender-based inequalities constrain their ability to enhance farm productivity and profitability. A key development strategy to close the gender gap focuses on empowering women within agricultural value chains, the wide-ranging set of activities that connect farmers to markets. Yet little is known about the effects of value chain development initiatives for empowering female farmers and addressing gender-based inequalities. This research uses a value chain approach and geospatial analysis to examine gender mainstreaming efforts in Uganda by comparing dairy value chains with active gender and-development programs with dairy value chains that do not have gender-specific programs. The results from this study will provide a better understanding of how female farmer participation in the marketplace facilitates women?s empowerment and improves farm productivity and food security in developing countries.

The objectives of this research are to: 1) Identify and measure how gender mainstreaming efforts affect women's participation in the value chain, gender equity in the household, and gender equity in the community; 2) Analyze the spatial and geographic consequences of women's empowerment at the individual, household, and community levels; and 3) Evaluate how examining gender within a spatial context assists in decision making for development programs. To accomplish this, a mixed method research approach will be used including: 1) surveys of female and male farmers engaged in the value chain; 2) in-depth interviews with female and male farmers from households engaged in the value chain, as well as key stakeholders throughout the value chain; 3) geospatial analysis; and 4) a randomized experiment. By conducting a theory directed, empirically grounded analysis of pro-poor value chain projects, this research can inform and shape the decisions of donor organizations, development practitioners, the private sector, and policy makers interested in targeting vulnerable populations through market based initiatives, as well as academics working in the areas of agriculture, gender, and development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Problem Statement: Gender-based inequalities constrain women’s ability to fully participate in efforts to enhance agricultural production and reduce poverty and food insecurity. For example, most women farmers in sub-Saharan African have limited access to agricultural assets, including large-livestock, land, and credit. To address these gender inequities and improve rural livelihoods, many development organizations have targeted women and mainstreamed gender within their agricultural aid programs. An important example of this was the East Africa Dairy Development (EADD) program (2008-2018), which was one of the leading market-oriented development initiatives in East Africa. The goal of EADD was to incorporate poor smallholder farmers into dairy value chains and cooperatives as a means for reducing poverty by increasing farmer incomes. EADD also sought to empower women and reduce gender inequities by increasing women’s ownership and access to dairy cows, and women’s incomes through increasing dairy productivity and sales of dairy products.

Goal: The goal of this research was to use the case study of EADD in Uganda to understand: 1) how dairy livestock development initiatives affect women’s levels of empowerment and gender equity, especially within the household and; 2) how spatial variables (e.g. distance to roads) intersect and effect develop efforts aimed at women’s empowerment and gender equity.

Methods: Between 2015-2017 we surveyed and conducted in-depth interviews with producers engaged in four EADD dairy producer cooperatives in Eastern and Central Uganda and two dairy producer organizations not involved in EADD programming. We used the Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index (WEAI) survey to survey a total of 340 households and 609 individual surveys for male and female heads of households in 6 rural sites (4 EADD and 2 non-EADD). The WEAI measures women's (dis)empowerment in agriculture in relation to production, resources, income, leadership, and time. We conducted in-depth interviews with 34 female and male farmers, 15 key stakeholders (EADD staff, extension agents), and four gender-segregated farmer focus groups. GIS waypoints were collected for each household surveyed, markets where milk was sold, and water tracks for select households to track distance traveled by individuals from households to water sources.

Findings: Our study found that access to dairy cows and milk markets provided important economic and welfare benefits for women and households. Access to dairy cows increased women's control and decision-making power over dairy production and income. Access to dairy cows also improved the social welfare of the household, especially in terms of household dietary diversity and nutrition and investment in educational opportunities for children. In our surveys, EADD participating households reported higher levels of milk consumption than non-participating households. Paying for school fees for children was the primary benefit of income from milk sales reported by male and female farmers.

A key finding was that access to dairy cows increased women’s time poverty: that is, they worked excessively long hours with insufficient time for rest or leisure due to competing claims on their time in terms of amount of work they must accomplish in productive and reproductive activities (e.g. childcare, preparing meals, working in the garden). While women and men both identified work burden as contributing to their disempowerment, a key difference was the significantly higher proportion of women who identified inadequate leisure time as a problem.

Dairy production increases the labor demand for smallholders, especially with improved breeds that require more inputs (e.g., water, feed and medicine) to maximize milk yields as well as more intensive production systems where the water and feed must be brought to the dairy cow. Our findings reveal that both men and women identify fetching water as one of the greatest challenges in maintaining dairy cows, but women and children disproportionately fetch the water and women have higher reported rates of time poverty. Women emphasized that the challenge of caring for the cows while maintaining their household labor responsibilities effected their personal wellbeing. However, women are not a homogenous category and our results show that women’s vulnerability to time poverty was influenced by their age, household economic status, access to clean water, and levels of empowerment regarding decision-making input for dairy production.

We also found water quality to be an issue, with smallholders struggling to provide clean water to cows. Producers reported dirty water caused cows to become ill, thereby contributing to higher costs for veterinary drugs and time poverty. In addition, water testing revealed select water sources with high nitrate levels that can be harmful for children and dairy cows.

Broader Impacts: Our findings contribute to the growing body of empirical research and theoretical literature on women’s empowerment, food security, and farm productivity. Our results help reveal how agricultural asset programs for livestock can act to empower and disempower women and men and address gender inequities in a culturally specific context. Identifying empowerment gaps is important for creating appropriate development policies and interventions.
